awd_titl_txt: CRII: SCH: Characterizing, Modeling and Evaluating Brain Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Brain dynamics, which reflects the healthy or pathological states of the brain with quantifiable, reproducible, and indicative dynamics values, remains the least understood and studied area of brain science despite its intrinsic and critical importance to the brain. Unlike other brain information such as the structural and sequential dimensions that have all been extensively studied with models and methods successfully developed, the 5th dimension, dynamics, has only very recently started receiving systematic analysis from the research community. The state-of-the-art models suffer from several fundamental limitations that have critically inhibited the accuracy and reliability of the dynamic parameters' computation. First, dynamic parameters are derived from each voxel of the brain spatially independently, and thus miss the fundamental spatial information since the brain is ?connected?. Second, current models rely solely on single-patient data to estimate the dynamic parameters without exploiting the big medical data consisting of billions of patients with similar diseases. 

This project aims to develop a framework for data-driven brain dynamics characterization, modeling and evaluation that includes the new concept of a 5th dimension - brain dynamics - to complement the structural 4-D brain for a complete picture. The project studies how dynamic computing of the brain as a distinct problem from the image reconstruction and de-noising of convention models, and analyzes the impact of different models for the dynamics analysis. A data-driven, scalable framework will be developed to depict the functionality and dynamics of the brain. This framework enables full utilization of 4-D brain spatio-temporal data and big medical data, resulting in accurate estimations of the dynamics of the brain that are not reflected in the voxel-independent models and the single patient models. The model and framework will be evaluated on both simulated and real dual-dose computed tomography perfusion image data and then compared with the state-of-the-art methods for brain dynamics computation by leveraging collaborations with Florida International University Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital / Weill Cornell Medical College (WCMC) and Northwell School of Medicine at Hofstra University. The proposed research will significantly advance the state-of-the-art in quantifying and analyzing brain structure and dynamics, and the interplay between the two for brain disease diagnosis, including both the acute and chronic diseases. This unified approach brings together fields of Computer Science, Bioengineering, Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuroradiology to create a framework for precisely measuring and analyzing the 5th dimension - brain dynamics - integrated with the 4-D brain with three dimensions from spatial data and one dimension from temporal data. Results from the project will be incorporated into graduate-level multi-disciplinary courses in machine learning, computational neuroscience and medical image analysis. This project will open up several new research directions in the domain of brain analysis, and will educate and nurture young researchers, advance the involvement of underrepresented minorities in computer science research, and equip them with new insights, models and tools for developing future research in brain dynamics in a minority serving university.

por.por_cntn:
Through the support of this NSF award, we have completed the proposed project on brain dynamics characterization, modeling, and evaluation.

 

Intellectual Merit:

We have investigated the computational model for the structural 4-dimensional (4-D) brain with dynamic modeling (the 5th dimension of the brain), and developed a series of data-driven, scalable frameworks to depict the functionality and dynamics of the brain. Specifically, we have designed and evaluated three classes of models for modeling brain dynamics in spatio-temporal neuroimaging data:

 

1. Dictionary learning and tensor total variation: We have explored dictionary learning and tensor total variation algorithms to learn patterns from the high-quality dynamic neuroimaging and apply the learned patterns to low-quality scans. This technique mitigates the need of high-quality data from the same subject by exploiting the local pattern similarities across subjects and spatio-temporal coherence within each subject. We have published our results in Neurocomputing and MICCAI.

 

2. Deep spatio-temporal networks: To investigate the non-linear mapping between high-dose and low-dose spatio-temporal neuroimaging data, we also explored deep neural network architectures for simultaneous spatial and temporal super-resolution and denoising. This network restores high-quality high-resolution neuroimaging volumes from the spatial and temporal cross-sections. We have published our work in Frontiers in Neurology, MICCAI, IEEE ISBI, and BMES.

 

3. Deep evolutionary networks: Deep neural networks usually have millions of parameters to learn and a large number of hyper-parameters to tune. Searching for the optimal network architecture and hyperparameters are time-consuming and laborious work. We designed and created a deep evolutionary network with expedited genetic algorithms to automatically evolve and create neural network structures for specific tasks. We have published this work in Medical Image Analysis, and MICCAI, and a U.S. patent pending.

 

Broader Impacts:

Teaching: This project provides new opportunities in interdisciplinary courses on the frontiers of machine learning, medical imaging, and health informatics. I have integrated medical image analysis and brain image restoration into the final project of my BME course ? Computer Applications for BME. Students from BME have chances to use MATLAB to analyze brain dynamic images and denoise the data using machine learning and medical image analysis derived from the products of this project. I also designed a new graduate ?level course Multimodal Data Mining, focusing on machine learning and data mining techniques for multimodal biomedical data analytics, including multimodal neuroimaging data.

Undergraduate training: The PI has trained four undergraduate students from Biomedical Engineering on deep learning for brain image analysis.

K?12 outreach: We have hosted outreach events at Cade Museum in 2019 to show brain image analysis software for K?12 students, and attracted great attention. The PI has mentored 3 high school students through the SSTP program at UF, and provide them hands?-on opportunities for machine learning and image analysis of neuroimaging.

Underrepresented: This project also involves one African American master student in our group who is supported by the Bridge to Ph.D. Fellowship and work on the brain imaging project. There is one female Ph.D. student in my research group. She has published 12 papers with me supported by this award so far. I am also mentoring 2 female master students and 2 female undergraduate students.
